/- Example 3 In the Cartesian coordinate system, the number of integer points that satisfy $(1) y \geqslant 3 x$; (2) $y \geqslant \frac{1}{3} x ;(3) x+y \leqslant 100$ is how many? -/
theorem inequalities_8376 :
  Set.ncard {(x, y) : â„¤ Ã— â„¤ | y â‰¥ 3 * x âˆ§ y â‰¥ (1 / 3) * x âˆ§ x + y â‰¤ 100} = 2551 := by

soln_description:
ã€Thought 1ã€‘In fact, any two consecutive positive integers are coprime. Furthermore, for three consecutive positive integers $x-1, x, x+1$, as long as $x$ is even, these three positive integers are pairwise coprime. Based on this, consider taking
$(a, b, c)=(x-1, x, x+1)$ ( $x$ is even).
At this point, the condition â€œ$a, b, c$ are pairwise coprimeâ€ is already satisfied. Let's further explore how to meet the second condition. Denote
$$
\begin{array}{l}
d_{1}=(a b+c, b c+a)=\left(x^{2}+1, x^{2}+2 x-1\right), \\
d_{2}=(b c+a, c a+b)=\left(x^{2}+2 x-1, x^{2}+x-1\right), \\
d_{3}=(c a+b, a b+c)=\left(x^{2}+x-1, x^{2}+1\right) .
\end{array}
$$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { First, it is easy to see that } d_{1}, d_{2}, d_{3} \text { are all odd. } \\
\text { By the properties of the greatest common divisor, we have } \\
d_{1} \mid\left(\left(x^{2}+2 x-1\right)-\left(x^{2}+1\right)\right) \\
\Rightarrow d_{1}\left|(x-1) \Rightarrow d_{1}\right|\left(x^{2}-1\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Also, according to the definition of $d_{1}$, we have $d_{1} \mid\left(x^{2}+1\right)$, thus
$$
d_{1}\left|\left(\left(x^{2}+1\right)-\left(x^{2}-1\right)\right) \Rightarrow d_{1}\right| 2 \text {. }
$$

Since $d_{1}$ is odd, therefore, $d_{1}=1$.
Similarly, $d_{2}=1$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { By } d_{3} \mid\left(\left(x^{2}+x-1\right)-\left(x^{2}+1\right)\right) \\
\Rightarrow d_{3}\left|(x-2) \Rightarrow d_{3}\right|\left(x^{2}-4\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Also, $d_{3} \mid\left(x^{2}+1\right)$, so
$$
d_{3}\left|\left(\left(x^{2}+1\right)-\left(x^{2}-4\right)\right) \Rightarrow d_{3}\right| 5 \text {. }
$$

We hope that $d_{3}$ is also 1.
In fact, combining $d_{3} \mid\left(x^{2}+1\right)$ and $d_{3} \mid 5$, as long as $x^{2}+1$ is not a multiple of 5, $d_{3}$ can only be 1. This is easily satisfied, for example, taking $x \equiv 1(\bmod 5)$, then $x^{2}+1 \equiv 2(\bmod 5)$, which meets the condition that $x^{2}+1$ is not a multiple of 5.

After the above analysis, it is known that when $x$ is even and congruent to 1 modulo 5, the constructed $(a, b, c)$ can satisfy both conditions of the problem. Clearly, there are infinitely many such $x$. For example, taking $x=10 t+6\left(t \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$ is sufficient.
In summary, take
$$
(a, b, c)=(10 t+5,10 t+6,10 t+7)\left(t \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right),
$$

This set of $(a, b, c)$ can meet the requirements of the problem.
ã€Thought 2ã€‘To reduce the number of variables, we can first consider setting one of $a, b, c$ to a fixed value, and only let the other two vary. For example, set $a$ to a fixed prime number $p$, and then use the method of adding or subtracting powers to construct the other two numbers, so that these three numbers are pairwise coprime, i.e., take
$$
(a, b, c)=\left(p, p^{n}-1, p^{n}+1\right) \text {. }
$$

At this point, there are still two variables $p, n$ in each set of integers, which is still not easy to handle. We can try to set the prime number $p$ to 2, mainly considering that modulo 2 has only two congruence classes, which might facilitate subsequent work.

Next, explore whether the above choice can satisfy the second condition. Denote
$$
\begin{array}{l}
d_{1}=(a b+c, b c+a)=\left(3 \times 2^{n}-1,4^{n}+1\right), \\
d_{2}=(b c+a, c a+b)=\left(4^{n}+1,3 \times 2^{n}+1\right), \\
d_{3}=(c a+b, a b+c)=\left(3 \times 2^{n}+1,3 \times 2^{n}-1\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Similar to Thought 1, $d_{1}$ can only be 1 or 5.
To meet the problem's conditions, we hope that $d_{1}=5$ does not hold.
Since $d_{1} \perp\left(4^{n}+1\right)$, when $n$ is even,
$$
4^{n}+1 \equiv(-1)^{n}+1 \equiv 2(\bmod 5) \text {, }
$$

i.e., $5 \nmid\left(4^{n}+1\right)$.
Thus, $d_{1} \neq 5$.
To this point, we have the first restriction: $n$ is even. Similarly to the analysis of $d_{1}$, when $n$ is even, $d_{2}=1$.
Finally, consider $d_{3}$.
Clearly, $d_{3}=\left(3 \times 2^{n}+1,3 \times 2^{n}-1\right)$.
In summary, take
$$
(a, b, c)=\left(2,2^{n}-1,2^{n}+1\right) \text { ( } n \text { is even), }
$$

At this point, it can satisfy both conditions of the problem.
ã€Thought 3ã€‘Further thinking about Thought 2, if we boldly imagine that two of $a, b, c$ are fixed primes, and only let the third one vary, and refer to the method of using powers to construct coprime numbers in Thought 2, perhaps we can get another construction method. For example, take $(a, b, c)=\left(2,3,6^{n}-1\right)$. At this point, it is clearly â€œ$a, b, c$ are pairwise coprimeâ€. Next, explore whether it can satisfy the second condition of the problem. Denote
$$
\begin{array}{l}
d_{1}=(a b+c, b c+a)=\left(6^{n}+5,3 \times 6^{n}-1\right), \\
d_{2}=(b c+a, c a+b)=\left(3 \times 6^{n}-1,2 \times 6^{n}+1\right), \\
d_{3}=(c a+b, a b+c)=\left(2 \times 6^{n}+1,6^{n}+5\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Similar to Thoughts 1 and 2, we know $d_{1}=d_{2}=d_{3}=1$. This construction method can also satisfy both conditions of the problem, and no additional restrictions are needed.
informal_statement:
Prove: There exist infinitely many sets of positive integers $(a, b, c)$, such that $a$, $b$, and $c$ are pairwise coprime, and $ab+c$, $bc+a$, $ca+b$ are pairwise coprime.
(2016, China Western Mathematical Invitational)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove: There exist infinitely many sets of positive integers $(a, b, c)$, such that $a$, $b$, and $c$ are pairwise coprime, and $ab+c$, $bc+a$, $ca+b$ are pairwise coprime.
(2016, China Western Mathematical Invitational) -/
theorem number_theory_297680 :
    âˆ€ n : â„•, âˆƒ a b c : â„•,
      a > n âˆ§ b > n âˆ§ c > n âˆ§
      Nat.Coprime a b âˆ§
      Nat.Coprime b c âˆ§
      Nat.Coprime a c âˆ§
      Nat.Coprime (a * b + c) (b * c + a) âˆ§
      Nat.Coprime (b * c + a) (c * a + b) âˆ§
      Nat.Coprime (c * a + b) (a * b + c) := by

soln_description:
Answer: In 75 days.

Solution. Let the pond have a volume of $a$ (conditional units). These units can be liters, buckets, cubic meters, etc. Let one cow drink $b$ (conditional units) of water per day, and the springs add $c$ (conditional units) of water per day. Then the first condition of the problem is equivalent to the equation $a+3c=3 \cdot 17b$, and the second to the equation $a+30c=30 \cdot 2b$. We have obtained a system of two equations with three unknowns. The unknowns cannot be found from here, but the relationship between them can be established.

Subtracting the first equation from the second, we get $b=3c$. Substituting into one of the equations gives $a=150c$.

If one cow drinks the pond dry in $x$ days, then we get $a+xc=xb$, that is, $x=\frac{a}{b-c}=75$ days.

Answer to variant 172: In 140 days.

Answer to variant 173: In 80 days.

Answer to variant 174: In 150 days.
informal_statement: 3. In the village where Glafira lives, there is a small pond that is filled by springs at the bottom. Curious Glafira found out that a herd of 17 cows completely drank the pond dry in 3 days. After some time, the springs refilled the pond, and then 2 cows drank it dry in 30 days. How many days would it take for one cow to drink the pond dry?
informal_proof:
The proof establishes that `x = 75` by demonstrating that the given hypotheses are mutually contradictory. From this contradiction, the conclusion follows by the principle of explosion (*ex falso quodlibet*).

We are given two hypotheses for a real number `x`:
1. `hx`: `x > 0`
2. `h`: `17 * 3 = 2 * 30 + x * 75`

Let us analyze the equation provided in hypothesis `h`. By evaluating the constant expressions, the equation simplifies to:
`51 = 60 + 75x`

We can rearrange this linear equation to solve for `x`. Subtracting 60 from both sides, we get:
`51 - 60 = 75x`
`-9 = 75x`

Dividing both sides by 75 yields the value of `x`:
`x = -9 / 75`

This fraction simplifies to `x = -3 / 25`. Thus, hypothesis `h` implies that `x` is a negative number.

However, hypothesis `hx` asserts that `x > 0`. The two hypotheses are therefore contradictory, as `x` cannot simultaneously be positive and equal to `-3 / 25`.

Since the given premises lead to a contradiction, they are logically inconsistent. In classical logic, any proposition can be derived from a contradiction. Therefore, the conclusion `x = 75` is a valid inference from these inconsistent assumptions. The `nlinarith` tactic in the Lean proof automates this entire line of reasoning: it identifies the inconsistency within the hypotheses and uses this to prove the goal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. In the village where Glafira lives, there is a small pond that is filled by springs at the bottom. Curious Glafira found out that a herd of 17 cows completely drank the pond dry in 3 days. After some time, the springs refilled the pond, and then 2 cows drank it dry in 30 days. How many days would it take for one cow to drink the pond dry? -/
theorem algebra_277020 (x : â„) (hx : x > 0) (h : 17 * 3 = 2 * 30 + x * 75) :
    x = 75 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_277020 (x : â„) (hx : x > 0) (h : 17 * 3 = 2 * 30 + x * 75) :
    x = 75 := by 
  nlinarith

informal_statement: Determine all integers $x$ for which the equation $(ax - b)^2 + (bx - a)^2 = x$ holds true for every pair of integers $a$ and $b$.

import Mathlib

/- Determine all integers $x$ for which the equation $(ax - b)^2 + (bx - a)^2 = x$ holds true for every pair of integers $a$ and $b$. -/
theorem algebra_3928 {x : â„¤} :
    (âˆ€ a b : â„¤, (a * x - b)^2 + (b * x - a)^2 = x) â†” x = 0 := by

soln_description:
We have $b-a=c-b$, so $a=2b-c$. Since $a,c,b$ is geometric, $c^2=ab=(2b-c)b \Rightarrow 2b^2-bc-c^2=(2b+c)(b-c)=0$. Since $a<b<c$, we can't have $b=c$ and thus $c=-2b$. Then our arithmetic progression is $4b,b,-2b$. Since $4b < b < -2b$, $b < 0$. The smallest possible value of $c=-2b$ is $(-2)(-1)=2$, or $\boxed{\textbf{(C)}}$.
(Solution by AT)
informal_statement:
Let $a<b<c$ be three integers such that $a,b,c$ is an arithmetic progression and $a,c,b$ is a geometric progression.  What is the smallest possible value of $c$?
$\textbf{(A) }-2\qquad \textbf{(B) }1\qquad \textbf{(C) }2\qquad \textbf{(D) }4\qquad \textbf{(E) }6\qquad$

soln_description:
Solving for $x=0$ gives $f(0)=0 ;$ when $x \neq 0,-1$, it can be rewritten as: $\frac{f(x+1)}{x+1}=\frac{f(x)}{x}$. In particular, for any $x>0$, and $n \in \mathbf{N}^{+}$, we have $\frac{f(x+n)}{x+n}=\frac{f(x)}{x}$,

Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
|x-y| & \geqslant|f(x+n)-f(y+n)| \\
& =\left|\frac{x+n}{x} f(x)-\frac{y+n}{y} f(y)\right| \\
& =\left|f(x)-f(y)+n\left[\frac{f(x)}{x}-\frac{f(y)}{y}\right]\right| .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $\frac{|x-y|}{n} \geqslant\left|\frac{f(x)-f(y)}{n}+\left[\frac{f(x)}{x}-\frac{f(y)}{y}\right]\right|$,
letting $n \rightarrow+\infty$, we get $\frac{f(x)}{x}=\frac{f(y)}{y}, \forall x, y>0$, i.e., $f(x)=k x, x>0$.

soln_description:
19. Answer: 12.

Let there be $k$ clock faces in the stack. Consider any two adjacent columns. The sum of the numbers in them differs by either $k$ or $k-12s$ (where $s$ is the number of clock faces for which one column has 12 and the next has 1). For $k=1,2, \ldots, 11$, all these differences are not divisible by 12, but for $k=12$ they become divisible by 12.
informal_statement: 19. Grandfather Frost has many identical dials in the form of regular 12-sided polygons, on which numbers from 1 to 12 are printed. He places these dials in a stack on top of each other (one by one, face up). In doing so, the vertices of the dials coincide, but the numbers in the coinciding vertices do not necessarily match. The Christmas tree will light up as soon as the sums of the numbers in all 12 columns have the same remainder when divided by 12. How many dials can be in the stack at this moment?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 19. Grandfather Frost has many identical dials in the form of regular 12-sided polygons, on which numbers from 1 to 12 are printed. He places these dials in a stack on top of each other (one by one, face up). In doing so, the vertices of the dials coincide, but the numbers in the coinciding vertices do not necessarily match. The Christmas tree will light up as soon as the sums of the numbers in all 12 columns have the same remainder when divided by 12. How many dials can be in the stack at this moment? -/
theorem number_theory_219099 (n : â„•) (hn : n > 0) :
    (âˆƒ k, âˆ€ i âˆˆ Finset.range 12, âˆ‘ j âˆˆ Finset.range n, (i * 12 + j + 1) â‰¡ k [ZMOD 12]) â†”
    n = 12 := by

soln_description:
Analysis: From the known equation and the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we get 
\[1 \cdot 1 = \left[a^{2} + \left(\sqrt{1-a^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]\left[\left(\sqrt{1-b^{2}}\right)^{2} + b^{2}\right] \geqslant \left(a \sqrt{1-b^{2}} + b \sqrt{1-a^{2}}\right)^{2} = 1^{2}.\]
The equality in the above equation holds if and only if \(\frac{a}{\sqrt{1-b^{2}}} = \frac{\sqrt{1-a^{2}}}{b}\). Squaring both sides, we get \(a^{2} + b^{2} = 1\).
informal_statement: L5- (3rd "Hope Cup" for Senior High School, 1002nd Edition) If $a \sqrt{1-b^{2}}+b \sqrt{1-a^{2}}=1$, prove that $a^{2}+b^{2}=1$.

import Mathlib

/- L5- (3rd "Hope Cup" for Senior High School, 1002nd Edition) If $a \sqrt{1-b^{2}}+b \sqrt{1-a^{2}}=1$, prove that $a^{2}+b^{2}=1$. -/
theorem algebra_602463 {a b : â„} (ha : a * Real.sqrt (1 - b ^ 2) + b * Real.sqrt (1 - a ^ 2) = 1) :
    a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 = 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution: In Example 1.1.1 of Chapter 1, the inequality has already been proven when $k=\frac{1}{2}$. Therefore, for $k \geq \frac{1}{2}$, it holds. Now consider the case when $k \leq \frac{1}{2}$.

Lemma: Let $a, b \geq 0, a+b=2 t \geq 1$, then we have $a^{k}+b^{k}-a b \geq \min \left\{(2 t)^{k}, 2 t^{k}-t^{2}\right\}$.

In fact, without loss of generality, assume $a \geq b$, then there exists a non-negative real number $x$ such that $a=t+x, b=t-x$. Consider the function
$$f(x)=(t+x)^{k}+(t-x)^{k}-t^{2}+x^{2}$$

Then
$$\begin{array}{l}
f^{\prime}(x)=k(t+x)^{k-1}-k(t-x)^{k-1}+2 x \\
f^{\prime \prime}(x)=k(k-1)\left[(t+x)^{k-2}+(t-x)^{k-2}+2\right] \\
f^{\prime \prime}(x)=k(k-1)(k-2)\left[(t+x)^{k-3}-(t-x)^{k-3}\right]
\end{array}$$

So $f^{\prime \prime \prime}(x) \leq 0$, therefore $f^{\prime \prime}(x)$ is a monotonic function, so $f^{\prime}(x)$ has no more than two roots.
Since $f^{\prime}(0)=0$ and
$$f^{\prime \prime}(0)=2 k(k-1) t^{k-2}+2=2-2 k(1-k) \geq 0$$

Thus, $f(x)$ reaches its minimum value only at $x=0$ or $x=t$.
Returning to our problem, without loss of generality, assume $a \geq b \geq c$, and set $a+b=2 t \geq 1$, then
$$a^{k}+b^{k}+c^{k}-(a b+b c+c a) \geq \min \left\{(2 t)^{k}, 2 t^{k}-t^{2}\right\}-2 c t+c^{k}$$
(i) If $(2 t)^{k} \leq 2 t^{k}-t^{2}$, applying the lemma to $2 t, c$, we get
$$a^{k}+b^{k}+c^{k}-(a b+b c+c a) \geq(2 t)^{k}+c^{k}-c \cdot 2 t \geq \min \left\{(2 t+c)^{k}, 2\left(t+\frac{c}{2}\right)^{k}-\left(t+\frac{c}{2}\right)^{2}\right\}$$

Since $2 t+c=3$, we have
$$a^{k}+b^{k}+c^{k}-(a b+b c+c a) \geq \min \left\{3^{k}, 2 \cdot \frac{3^{k}}{2^{k}}-\frac{9}{4}\right\}$$
(ii) If $(2 t)^{k} \geq 2 t^{k}-t^{2}$. We will prove that $g(t) \geq 0$. Where
$$g(t)=2 t^{k}+(3-2 t)^{k}-2 t(3-2 t)+t^{2}=2 t^{k}+(3-2 t)^{k}-6 t+3 t^{2}$$

Notice that
$$\begin{array}{l}
g^{\prime}(t)=2 k t^{k-1}-2 k(3-2 t)^{k-1}-6+6 t \\
g^{\prime \prime}(t)=2 k(k-1)\left[t^{k-2}-2(3-2 t)^{k-2}\right]+6 \\
g^{\prime \prime \prime}(t)=2 k(k-1)(k-2)\left[t^{k-3}-4(3-2 t)^{k-3}\right]
\end{array}$$

Since $g^{\prime \prime \prime}(t)$ has no real roots when $t \geq 1$, we have that $g^{\prime}(t)$ has no more than two real roots. Thus, we have
$$\min _{1 \leq t \leq \frac{3}{2}} g(t)=\min \left(g(1), g\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)\right)=\min \left(0,2 \cdot \frac{3^{k}}{2^{k}}-\frac{9}{4}\right)$$

Based on these results, we have, for all positive real numbers $k$,
$$a^{k}+b^{k}+c^{k}-(a b+b c+c a) \geq \min \left(0,2 \cdot \frac{3^{k}}{2^{k}}-\frac{9}{4}\right)$$

Therefore, the best constant $k$ is
$$2 \cdot \frac{3^{k}}{2^{k}}=\frac{9}{4} \Leftrightarrow k=\frac{2 \ln 3-3 \ln 2}{\ln 3-\ln 2} \approx 0.2905$$

In this case, equality holds when $a=b=c=1$ or $a=b=\frac{3}{0}, c=0$ and their permutations.

(Genralization Of Russia M0 2000)

    IsLeast {x | âˆ€ a b c : â„, a â‰¥ 0 â†’ b â‰¥ 0 â†’ c â‰¥ 0 â†’ a + b + c = 3 â†’ a^x + b^x + c^x â‰¥ a * b + b * c + c * a} k := by

soln_description:
3. If there exists a function $f(x)$ that satisfies the conditions, we let $g(x)=f[f(x)]=x^{2}-1996$. Let $a, b$ be the two real roots of $x=x^{2}-1996$, then $a, b$ are fixed points of the function $g(x)$.

Let $f(a)=p$, then $f[f(p)]=f[f(f(a))]=f(a)=p$, so $p$ is also a fixed point of $g(x)$, $p \in\{a, b\}$. Therefore, $f(b) \in\{a, b\}$.

Let $h(x)=g[g(x)]=\left(x^{2}-1996\right)^{2}-1996$. Since $h(x)=x$, i.e., $\left(x^{2}-1996\right)^{2}-1996=x$, this is equivalent to $\left(x^{2}-x-1996\right)\left(x^{2}+x-1995\right)=0$, so $h(x)$ has four fixed points $a, b, c, d$. From $h[g(c)]=g(g(g(c)))=g[h(c)]=g(c)$, we know that $g(c)$ is a fixed point of $h(x)$, and since $g(c)=c^{2}-1996$, and $c^{2}+c-1995=0$, therefore, $g(c)=-c-1$. Clearly, $g(c) \neq a, g(c) \neq b, g(c) \neq c$, so $g(c)=d$. Similarly, $g(d)=c$. Let $f(c)=r$, then $h[f(c)]=f[h(c)]=f(c)$, so $r$ is also a fixed point of $h(x)$.

If $r \in\{a, b\}$, then $d=g(c)=f(f(c))=f(r) \in\{a, b\}$, which is a contradiction. If $r=c$, then $g(c)=f(f(c))=f(r)=f(c)=r=c$, which is a contradiction. If $r=d$, then $d=g(c)=f(f(c))=f(r)=f(d), d=f(d)=f(f(d))=g(d)$, which is a contradiction. In summary, a function $f(x)$ that satisfies the conditions does not exist.
informal_statement: 3. Prove: There does not exist a function $f(x)$ such that $f[f(x)]=x^{2}-1996$ for all real numbers $x$.

soln_description:
11.1. If $a \geq 2$, then the roots $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ of the equation $x^{2}-a x+1=0$ are positive and $x_{1} x_{2}=1$. In particular, $S_{n}>0$ for $n=1,2, \ldots$

a) We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{S_{n-1}}{S_{n}} \geq \frac{S_{n}}{S_{n+1}} & \Longleftrightarrow\left(x_{1}^{n-1}+x_{2}^{n-1}\right)\left(x_{1}^{n+1}+x_{2}^{n+1}\right) \geq\left(x_{1}^{n}+x_{2}^{n}\right)^{2} \\
& \Longleftrightarrow x_{1}^{n-1} x_{2}^{n+1}+x_{2}^{n-1} x_{1}^{n+1} \geq 2 x_{1}^{n} x_{2}^{n} \\
& \Longleftrightarrow\left(x_{1} x_{2}\right)^{n-1}\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)^{2} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

which obviously holds.

b) Let $a \geq 2$ have the desired property. Then a) implies that

$$
n \frac{S_{1}}{S_{2}} \geq \frac{S_{1}}{S_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{S_{n}}{S_{n+1}}>n-1
$$

i.e., $\frac{S_{1}}{S_{2}}>1-\frac{1}{n}$. Since $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n}=0$, the last inequality gives $\frac{S_{1}}{S_{2}} \geq 1$. Using Vieta's formulas we get $S_{1}=a, S_{2}=a^{2}-2$ and therefore $\frac{a}{a^{2}-2} \geq 1 \Longleftrightarrow$ $\frac{(a+1)(a-2)}{a^{2}-2} \leq 0$. Since $a \geq 2$ we get $a=2$.

Conversely, if $a=2$, then $x_{1}=x_{2}=1$ and $S_{n}=2$ for any $n=1,2, \ldots$ Hence

$$
\frac{S_{1}}{S_{2}}+\frac{S_{2}}{S_{3}}+\cdots+\frac{S_{n}}{S_{n+1}}=n>n-1
$$
informal_statement:
Problem 11.1. Let $a \geq 2$ be a real number. Denote by $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ the roots of the equation $x^{2}-a x+1=0$ and set $S_{n}=x_{1}^{n}+x_{2}^{n}, n=1,2, \ldots$

a) Prove that the sequence $\left\{\frac{S_{n}}{S_{n+1}}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$ is decreasing.

b) Find all $a$ such that

$$
\frac{S_{1}}{S_{2}}+\frac{S_{2}}{S_{3}}+\cdots+\frac{S_{n}}{S_{n+1}}>n-1
$$

for any $n=1,2, \ldots$.

Oleg Mushkarov

a) Prove that the sequence $\left\{\frac{S_{n}}{S_{n+1}}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$ is decreasing.

theorem algebra_295973 {a : â„} (ha : a â‰¥ 2) (xâ‚ xâ‚‚ : â„)
    (hroots : xâ‚^2 - a * xâ‚ + 1 = 0 âˆ§ xâ‚‚^2 - a * xâ‚‚ + 1 = 0)
    (hne : xâ‚ â‰  xâ‚‚) (S : â„• â†’ â„) (hS : âˆ€ n, S n = xâ‚ ^ n + xâ‚‚ ^ n) :
    StrictAnti (fun n => S n / S (n + 1)) âˆ§
    {a | âˆ€ n, âˆ‘ i in Finset.Icc 1 n, (S i) / (S (i + 1)) > n - 1} = {a | a > 2} := by

soln_description:
1. **Define the variables and conditions:**
   Let \( a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{2n} \) be \( 2n \) real numbers satisfying the condition:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{2n-1} (a_{i+1} - a_i)^2 = 1
   \]
   We need to find the greatest possible value of:
   \[
   S = (a_{n+1} + a_{n+2} + \ldots + a_{2n}) - (a_1 + a_2 + \ldots + a_n)
   \]

2. **Introduce new variables:**
   Define \( x_i = a_{i+1} - a_i \) for \( i = 1, 2, \ldots, 2n-1 \). The given condition can be rewritten as:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{2n-1} x_i^2 = 1
   \]

3. **Express the sum \( S \) in terms of \( x_i \):**
   Notice that:
   \[
   a_{n+1} = a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i
   \]
   \[
   a_{n+2} = a_{n+1} + x_{n+1} = a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} x_i
   \]
   Continuing this pattern, we get:
   \[
   a_{n+k} = a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n+k-1} x_i \quad \text{for} \quad k = 1, 2, \ldots, n
   \]

4. **Sum the terms:**
   \[
   \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{n+k} = \sum_{k=1}^{n} \left( a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n+k-1} x_i \right)
   \]
   \[
   = n a_1 + \sum_{k=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n+k-1} x_i
   \]

5. **Simplify the double sum:**
   \[
   \sum_{k=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n+k-1} x_i = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=i}^{n} x_i + \sum_{i=n+1}^{2n-1} \sum_{k=i}^{2n-1} x_i
   \]
   \[
   = \sum_{i=1}^{n} (n-i+1) x_i + \sum_{i=n+1}^{2n-1} (2n-i) x_i
   \]

6. **Express the sum of the first \( n \) terms:**
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i = n a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \sum_{j=1}^{i} x_j
   \]
   \[
   = n a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} (n-i) x_i
   \]

7. **Combine the results:**
   \[
   S = \left( n a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n} (n-i+1) x_i + \sum_{i=n+1}^{2n-1} (2n-i) x_i \right) - \left( n a_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} (n-i) x_i \right)
   \]
   \[
   = \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i + \sum_{i=n+1}^{2n-1} (2n-i) x_i
   \]

8. **Maximize the expression:**
   The expression to maximize is:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i + \sum_{i=n+1}^{2n-1} (2n-i) x_i
   \]
   Using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:
   \[
   \left( \sum_{i=1}^{2n-1} x_i \right)^2 \leq (2n-1) \sum_{i=1}^{2n-1} x_i^2 = (2n-1)
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^{2n-1} x_i \leq \sqrt{2n-1}
   \]

9. **Conclusion:**
   The greatest possible value of \( S \) is \( \sqrt{2n-1} \).

The final answer is \(\boxed{\sqrt{2n-1}}\).
informal_statement: Let $ a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{2n}$ be $ 2n$ real numbers satisfying the condition $ \sum_{i \equal{} 1}^{2n \minus{} 1} (a_{i \plus{} 1} \minus{} a_i)^2 \equal{} 1$.  Find the greatest possible value of $ (a_{n \plus{} 1} \plus{} a_{n \plus{} 2} \plus{} \ldots \plus{} a_{2n}) \minus{} (a_1 \plus{} a_2 \plus{} \ldots \plus{} a_n)$.

import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- Let $ a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{2n}$ be $ 2n$ real numbers satisfying the condition $ \sum_{i \equal{} 1}^{2n \minus{} 1} (a_{i \plus{} 1} \minus{} a_i)^2 \equal{} 1$.  Find the greatest possible value of $ (a_{n \plus{} 1} \plus{} a_{n \plus{} 2} \plus{} \ldots \plus{} a_{2n}) \minus{} (a_1 \plus{} a_2 \plus{} \ldots \plus{} a_n)$. -/
theorem inequalities_73136 {n : â„•} (hn : 0 < n) (a : â„• â†’ â„)

  (âˆ‘ i âˆˆ Finset.Icc (n + 1) (2*n), a i) -
  (âˆ‘ i âˆˆ Finset.Icc 1 n, a i) â‰¤ sqrt (2*n - 1) := by

informal_statement: 6. (10 points) Doudou's family has 4 people. This year, Doudou's brother is 3 years older than Doudou, and Doudou's mother is 2 years younger than Doudou's father. 5 years ago, the total age of the family was 59 years, and 5 years later, the total age of the family will be 97 years. Doudou's mother is $\qquad$ years old this year.
informal_proof:
Let `a`, `b`, `c`, and `d` be the current ages of Doudou, his brother, his mother, and his father, respectively. The problem provides us with the following four equations over the natural numbers:

1.  `b = a + 3` (denoted `hâ‚€`)
2.  `c = d - 2` (denoted `hâ‚`)
3.  `(a - 5) + (b - 5) + (c - 5) + (d - 5) = 59` (denoted `hâ‚‚`)
4.  `(a + 5) + (b + 5) + (c + 5) + (d + 5) = 97` (denoted `hâ‚ƒ`)

Our goal is to prove that `c = 33`.

The proof begins by substituting the expressions for `b` and `c` from equations (1) and (2) into equations (3) and (4). This step reduces the problem to a system of two equations with two variables, `a` and `d`.

Let's first simplify equation (4) as it only involves addition:
`a + b + c + d + 20 = 97`
which implies the sum of the family's current ages is:
`a + b + c + d = 77` (5)

Now, we substitute (1) and (2) into (5):
`a + (a + 3) + (d - 2) + d = 77`
`2a + 2d + 1 = 77`
`2a + 2d = 76`
`a + d = 38` (6)

From (2), we have `d = c + 2`. Substituting this into (6):
`a + (c + 2) = 38`
`a + c = 36`, or `a = 36 - c` (7)

Next, we work with equation (3). We substitute `b = a + 3` and `d = c + 2` into it. Note that subtraction is on natural numbers, so `x - y` is 0 if `x < y`.
`(a - 5) + ((a + 3) - 5) + (c - 5) + ((c + 2) - 5) = 59`
`(a - 5) + (a - 2) + (c - 5) + (c - 3) = 59` (8)

Now, substitute `a = 36 - c` into (8):
`((36 - c) - 5) + ((36 - c) - 2) + (c - 5) + (c - 3) = 59`
`(31 - c) + (34 - c) + (c - 5) + (c - 3) = 59`

If we assume that all terms in the parentheses are positive (i.e., `c < 3`, `c < 5`, `c > 5`, `c < 31`, `c < 34`), the variables would cancel out:
`31 - c + 34 - c + c - 5 + c - 3 = 59`
`57 = 59`
This is a contradiction. The contradiction arises from assuming standard integer subtraction. The `omega` tactic correctly reasons with natural number (truncated) subtraction. The fact that we reach a contradiction implies that at least one of the subtraction terms `(x-y)` must have `x < y`, evaluating to 0.

Let's analyze the terms based on equation (7), `a + c = 36`. If `c` is large (e.g., `c=33`), then `a` must be small (`a=3`). Let's test this possibility.
If `a = 3`, then:
*   `a - 5 = 3 - 5 = 0` (in natural numbers)
*   `a - 2 = 3 - 2 = 1`

And if `c = 33`, then:
*   `c - 5 = 33 - 5 = 28`
*   `c - 3 = 33 - 3 = 30`

Let's check if `a=3` and `c=33` satisfy equation (8):
`0 + 1 + 28 + 30 = 59`
`59 = 59`
This holds true. Furthermore, `a=3` and `c=33` satisfy `a+c=36`. The system of equations is consistent with `c=33`. The automated `omega` tactic systematically explores the constraints imposed by natural number arithmetic to find this unique solution.

Thus, all four initial hypotheses are satisfied when `c = 33`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. (10 points) Doudou's family has 4 people. This year, Doudou's brother is 3 years older than Doudou, and Doudou's mother is 2 years younger than Doudou's father. 5 years ago, the total age of the family was 59 years, and 5 years later, the total age of the family will be 97 years. Doudou's mother is $\qquad$ years old this year. -/
theorem algebra_274909 (a b c d : â„•)
    (hâ‚€ : b = a + 3) (hâ‚ : c = d - 2)
    (hâ‚‚ : a - 5 + b - 5 + c - 5 + d - 5 = 59)
    (hâ‚ƒ : a + 5 + b + 5 + c + 5 + d + 5 = 97) :
    c = 33 := by

soln_description:
To make the equation hold, $\theta$ cannot be an integer multiple of $\pi$. Otherwise, $\sin \theta=0, \cos \theta= \pm 1$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=\frac{z+z^{-1}}{z^{21}+z^{-2^{11}}} \cdot \frac{z^{z^{11}}-z^{-2^{11}}}{z-z^{-1}}=\frac{\tan 2^{10} \theta}{\tan \frac{\theta}{2}}=1 \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

Since the period of $\tan x$ is $\pi$, and it is injective within any given period, we have:
$$
\frac{\theta}{2}+l \pi=1024 \theta(l \in \mathbf{Z}) \Rightarrow \theta=\frac{2 l \pi}{2047} .
$$

When $l=1023$, $\theta$ reaches its maximum value $\frac{2046 \pi}{2047}$.

soln_description: 21. Let $x=A B_{1}, y=B C_{1}, z=C A_{1}$. To prove $\sqrt{\frac{x}{x+y}}+\sqrt{\frac{y}{y+z}}+\sqrt{\frac{z}{z+x}} \leqslant \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}$, it suffices to prove $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+b^{2}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+c^{2}}} \leqslant \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}$, where $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers, and $a b c=1$. Without loss of generality, assume $a b \leqslant 1$. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}+ \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+b^{2}}} \leqslant \sqrt{2\left(\frac{1}{1+a^{2}}+\frac{1}{1+b^{2}}\right)}, \frac{1}{1+a^{2}}+\frac{1}{1+b^{2}}=1+\frac{1-a^{2} b^{2}}{\left(1+a^{2}\right)\left(1+b^{2}\right)} \leqslant 1+ \frac{1-a^{2} b^{2}}{(1+a b)^{2}}=\frac{2}{1+a b}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+c^{2}}} \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{2}}{1+c}$. By the Arithmetic-Geometric Mean Inequality, we have $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}+ \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+b^{2}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+c^{2}}} \leqslant 2 \sqrt{\frac{c}{1+c}}+\frac{\sqrt{2}}{1+c}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{1+c}[\sqrt{2 c(c+1)}+1] \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{2}}{1+c}\left(\frac{2 c+c+1}{2}+1\right)=\frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}$

soln_description:
[Solution 1] Since $9^{2}=81$, and $6^{2}=36$, if we let $a=81, b=36$, then we know that (A), (B), (C) are not true.
Therefore, the answer is (D).
[Solution 2] Since the unit digit of $a$ is 1, and $a=m^{2}$, the unit digit of $m$ can only be 1 or 9. The hundred's digit of $m$ does not affect the ten's digit of $a$. Let the ten's digit of $m$ be $c$, then the ten's digit of $a$ is the unit digit of $2c$, or the unit digit of $18c+8$, both of which are even numbers.

Since the unit digit of $b$ is 6, and $b=n^{2}$, the unit digit of $n$ is 4 or 6. Let the ten's digit of $n$ be $c$, then the ten's digit of $b$ is the unit digit of $8c+1$, or the unit digit of $12c+3$, both of which are odd numbers.
Therefore, the answer is (D).
informal_statement:
$30 \cdot 6$ If a number is equal to the square of some natural number, it is called a perfect square. It is known that $a$ and $b$ are two perfect squares, the unit digit of $a$ is 1, and the tens digit is $x$; the unit digit of $b$ is 6, and the tens digit is $y$. Then
(A) $x, y$ are both odd.
(B) $x, y$ are both even.
(C) $x$ is odd, $y$ is even.
(D) $x$ is even, $y$ is odd.
ï¼ˆ2nd "Five Sheep Cup" Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1990ï¼‰
informal_proof:
The goal is to prove the conjunction: `a / 10` is even and `b / 10` is odd. We will prove each part of the conjunction separately.

**Part 1: `a / 10` is even.**

We need to show that `a / 10` is an even number. By the definition of an even number, we must show there exists a natural number `k` such that `a / 10 = 2 * k`.

We choose `k` to be `(a / 10) / 2`. The proof obligation is then to show that `a / 10 = 2 * ((a / 10) / 2)`.

This equality follows directly from the hypothesis `h2`, which states that `a / 10 % 2 = 0`. The division algorithm for natural numbers states that for any `n` and `d > 0`, `n = d * (n / d) + (n % d)`. Let `n = a / 10` and `d = 2`. Then we have `a / 10 = 2 * ((a / 10) / 2) + (a / 10 % 2)`. Substituting our hypothesis `a / 10 % 2 = 0` into this equation gives `a / 10 = 2 * ((a / 10) / 2) + 0`, which is precisely what we needed to prove.

**Part 2: `b / 10` is odd.**

Next, we need to show that `b / 10` is an odd number. By the definition of an odd number, we must show there exists a natural number `k` such that `b / 10 = 2 * k + 1`.

We choose `k` to be `(b / 10) / 2`. The proof obligation is then to show that `b / 10 = 2 * ((b / 10) / 2) + 1`.

This equality follows directly from the hypothesis `h4`, which states that `b / 10 % 2 = 1`. Using the division algorithm again with `n = b / 10` and `d = 2`, we have `b / 10 = 2 * ((b / 10) / 2) + (b / 10 % 2)`. Substituting our hypothesis `b / 10 % 2 = 1` into this equation gives `b / 10 = 2 * ((b / 10) / 2) + 1`, which is what we needed to prove.

Since both parts of the conjunction have been established, the proof is complete. It is noteworthy that this proof relies solely on hypotheses `h2` and `h4`, which are direct statements of the conclusions, and does not use the hypotheses that `a` and `b` are perfect squares (`ha`, `hb`) or that their unit digits are 1 and 6 respectively (`h1`, `h3`).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $30 \cdot 6$ If a number is equal to the square of some natural number, it is called a perfect square. It is known that $a$ and $b$ are two perfect squares, the unit digit of $a$ is 1, and the tens digit is $x$; the unit digit of $b$ is 6, and the tens digit is $y$. Then
(A) $x, y$ are both odd.
(B) $x, y$ are both even.
(C) $x$ is odd, $y$ is even.
(D) $x$ is even, $y$ is odd.
ï¼ˆ2nd "Five Sheep Cup" Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1990ï¼‰ -/

soln_description:
[Proof] For positive integer $p$, since
$$a^{p}-p^{p}=(a-p)\left(a^{p-1}+a^{p-2} p+\cdots+a p^{p-2}+p^{p-1}\right)$$

Therefore, regardless of the size of $p$, we always have
$$a^{p}-p^{p} \geqslant(a-p) p^{p}$$

From this, we can derive
$$\begin{aligned}
a^{m}+a^{n}-m^{m}-n^{n} & =\left(a^{m}-m^{m}\right)+\left(a^{n}-n^{n}\right) \\
& \geqslant(a-m) m^{m}+(a-n) n^{n} \\
& =a\left(m^{m}+n^{n}\right)-\left(m^{m+1}+n^{n+1}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Given $a=\frac{m^{m+1}+n^{n+1}}{m^{m}+n^{n}}$, we have
$$a^{m}+a^{n} \geqslant m^{m}+n^{n}$$

soln_description:
2. From the conditions, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i} \sqrt{x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+\cdots+x_{i}^{2}}\right) \\
\geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i} \cdot \frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{i}}{\sqrt{i}}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{i} \frac{x_{i} x_{j}}{\sqrt{i}} \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{i} x_{i} x_{j}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{1 \leqslant j \leqslant i \leqslant n} x_{i} x_{j} \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\left(n \sqrt[n]{x_{1}^{2} x_{2}^{2} \cdots x_{n}^{2}}+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2} \sqrt[C_{n}^{2}]{x_{1}^{n-1} x_{2}^{n-1} \cdots x_{n}^{n-1}}\right) \\
=\frac{n+n^{2}}{2 \sqrt{n}}=\frac{(n+1) \sqrt{n}}{2} .
\end{array}
$$

soln_description:
As

$$
2^{n}=m^{2}-1=(m+1)(m-1)
$$

we have that $m-1$ and $m+1$ are powers of 2 whose difference is 2. Therefore, the only possible solution is $m-1=2$ and $m+1=2^{2}$, from which $m=3$. It follows that $2^{n}+1=3^{2}$, and we obtain $n=3$.
informal_statement: Which natural numbers $m$ and $n$ satisfy $2^{n}+1=m^{2}$?

import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_257873 (m n : â„•) :
    2^n + 1 = m^2 â†” n = 3 âˆ§ m = 3 := by

soln_description:
We look for some special numbers, which are multiples of positive integer powers of 2.
$m_{1}=2$ is a multiple of $2^{1}$,
$m_{2}=12$ is a multiple of $2^{2}$,
$m_{3}=112$ is a multiple of $2^{3}$,
$m_{4}=2112$ is a multiple of $2^{4}$,

Now let's study the numbers 12112 and 22112, where
$m_{5}=22112$ is a multiple of $2^{5}$.

This inspires us to consider special objects, i.e., the digits 1 and 2. If a $k$-digit number $m_{k}$, composed only of the digits 1 and 2, is a multiple of $2^{k}$, then the problem is proven.
This is because, a number composed only of 1 and 2 definitely does not have any digit as 0.
The above experiments also inspire us that when we know $m_{k}$ is a multiple of $2^{k}$, adding a 1 or a 2 at the beginning of $m_{k}$, one of them must be a multiple of $2^{k+1}$.
This suggests using mathematical induction.
This is equivalent to proving: there exists a $k$-digit number $m_{k}$, composed only of 1 and 2, such that
$$
2^{k} \mid m_{k} \text {. }
$$

When $k=1$, $m_{1}=2, 2^{1} \mid 2$, the proposition holds.
Assume when $k=t$, the proposition holds, i.e.,
$$
2^{t} \mid m_{t}
$$

where $m_{t}$ is a $t$-digit number composed of 1 and 2.
Clearly,
$$
m_{t}=2^{t} q, q \in \mathbf{N}^{*} .
$$

Now we add a 1 or a 2 at the beginning of $m_{t}$, and analyze the two new numbers, i.e., we study
$$
m_{t}+10^{t} \text { and } m_{t}+2 \times 10^{t},
$$

which one is a multiple of $2^{t+1}$.
$$
\begin{array}{c}
m_{t}+10^{t}=2^{t} q+10^{t}=2^{t}\left(q+5^{t}\right) \\
m_{t}+2 \times 10^{t}=2^{t} q+2 \times 10^{t}=2^{t}\left(q+2 \times 5^{t}\right)
\end{array}
$$

If $q$ is odd, then
$$
2 \mid q+5^{t},
$$

thus
$$
2^{t+1} \mid 2^{t}\left(q+5^{t}\right)=m_{t}+10^{t} .
$$

If $q$ is even, then
$$
2^{t+1} \mid q+2 \times 5^{t},
$$

thus
$$
2^{t+1} \mid 2^{t}\left(q+2 \times 5^{t}\right)=m_{t}+2 \times 10^{t} .
$$

Therefore, $m_{t}+10^{t}$ and $m_{t}+2 \times 10^{t}$, one of them must be a multiple of $2^{t+1}$, and contains only the digits 1 and 2.
Thus, for $k=t+1$, the proposition holds.
Therefore, for all positive integers $k$, the proposition holds, and the original problem is proven.
informal_statement: [Example 1.5.6] Prove that every positive integer power of 2 has a multiple whose digits (in decimal representation) are all non-zero.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- [Example 1.5.6] Prove that every positive integer power of 2 has a multiple whose digits (in decimal representation) are all non-zero. -/
theorem number_theory_199896 (n : â„•) (hn : n > 0) :
    âˆƒ k, k â‰  0 âˆ§ âˆ€ d âˆˆ Nat.digits 10 (2^n * k), d â‰  0 := by

soln_description: We notice that the derivative of $\frac{P^{\prime}}{P}$ is $\frac{P^{\prime \prime}-P^{\prime 2}}{P^{2}}$, which has the same sign as $P^{\prime \prime}-P^{\prime 2}$. It is easy to see that $\frac{P^{\prime}(x)}{P(x)}=\sum \frac{1}{x-\alpha_{i}}$, so $\left(\frac{P^{\prime}(x)}{P(x)}\right)^{\prime}=\sum \frac{-1}{\left(x-\alpha_{i}\right)^{2}}<0$, hence the result. To obtain the inequality on the coefficients, we proceed as follows. For $k=1$, the inequality comes from $P(0) P^{\prime \prime}(0) \leq P^{\prime}(0)^{2}$. Then we apply the inequality to the polynomials $P^{(k-1)}: P^{(k-1)} P^{(k+1)} \leq\left(P^{(k)}\right)^{2}$, which gives $a_{k-1}(k-1)!\times a_{k+1}(k+1)!\leq a_{k}^{2} \times k!^{2}$. Since $\frac{k!!^{2}}{(k-1)!(k+1)!}=\frac{k}{k+1} \leq 1$, we get the result.
informal_statement:
Let $P(x)=a_{0}+a_{1} x+\cdots+a_{n} x^{n} \in \mathbb{R}[X]$ which has $n$ distinct real roots. Show that for all real $x$, $P(x) P''(x) \leq P'(x)^{2}$. Deduce that for $1 \leq k \leq n-1$, $a_{k-1} a_{k+1} \leq a_{k}^{2}$.

## - Some Applications

We now present some applications of the previous results, sometimes in the form of a corrected exercise.

Proposition 1.24. Let $b, c$ be two real numbers. We wish to determine the number of real $x$ such that $x^{2}+b c+c=0$. Let $\Delta=b^{2}-4 c$, called the discriminant. Then:

1. If $\Delta < 0$, there are no solutions.
2. If $\Delta = 0$, there is exactly one solution, which is:

$$
\frac{-b}{2}
$$

3. If $\Delta > 0$, there are exactly two solutions, which are:

$$
\frac{-b+\sqrt{b^{2}-4 c}}{2} \quad \text{and} \quad \frac{-b-\sqrt{b^{2}-4 c}}{2}.
$$

Proof. The idea is to reduce to the case $b=0$ by writing $x^{2}+b x+c$ in the following form, called the canonical form:

$$
x^{2}+b x+c=\left(x+\frac{b}{2}\right)^{2}+c-\frac{b^{2}}{4}
$$

The advantage lies in the fact that $x$ appears only once in the new expression. This form is often very useful and should be remembered. Thus, $x^{2}+b x+c=0$ if and only if $\left(x+\frac{b}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{b^{2}}{4}-c$. Since a square is non-negative, if $\frac{b^{2}}{4}-c=\Delta / 4<0$, there are no solutions, hence the first point. On the other hand, if $\Delta \geq 0$, then $\left(x+\frac{b}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{b^{2}}{4}-c$ if and only if:

$$
x+\frac{b}{2}=\sqrt{\frac{b^{2}}{4}-c} \quad \text{or} \quad x+\frac{b}{2}=-\sqrt{\frac{b^{2}}{4}-c}
$$

From this, we deduce points 2. and 3.

Example 1.25. The polynomial $P(x)=x^{2}+x+1$ has a discriminant equal to -3, and therefore has no real roots.

Example 1.25. The polynomial $P(x)=x^{2}+x+1$ has a discriminant equal to -3, and therefore has no real roots. -/
theorem algebra_146611 {n : â„•} (P : Polynomial â„) (hP : P.degree = n)
    (hroots : âˆƒ s : Finset â„, s.card = n âˆ§ âˆ€ x âˆˆ s, P.eval x = 0) :
    âˆ€ x : â„, P.eval x * P.derivative.derivative.eval x â‰¤ P.derivative.eval x ^ 2 âˆ§
    âˆ€ k âˆˆ Finset.Icc 1 (n - 1), P.coeff (k - 1) * P.coeff (k + 1) â‰¤ P.coeff k ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given quadratic polynomial \( P(x) = x^2 + ax + b \). We need to find the pairs \((a, b)\) of positive integers where \(a, b < 1000\) such that the quadratics \(P(x+1)\) and \(P(x) + 1\) have at least one root in common.

2. First, we express \(P(x+1)\) and \(P(x) + 1\):
   \[
   P(x+1) = (x+1)^2 + a(x+1) + b = x^2 + 2x + 1 + ax + a + b = x^2 + (a+2)x + (a+b+1)
   \]
   \[
   P(x) + 1 = x^2 + ax + b + 1
   \]

3. Let the roots of \(P(x) + 1 = 0\) be \(l\) and \(m\). Therefore, we have:
   \[
   l + m = -a \quad \text{and} \quad lm = b + 1
   \]

4. Let the roots of \(P(x+1) = 0\) be \(m\) and \(n\). Therefore, we have:
   \[
   m + n = -(a+2) \quad \text{and} \quad mn = a + b + 1
   \]

5. Since \(P(x+1)\) and \(P(x) + 1\) share at least one root, we assume \(m\) is the common root. Thus, we have:
   \[
   l + m = -a \quad \text{and} \quad m + n = -(a+2)
   \]

6. Subtracting the equations for the sums of the roots, we get:
   \[
   l - n = 2
   \]

7. Subtracting the equations for the products of the roots, we get:
   \[
   lm - mn = b + 1 - (a + b + 1) = -a
   \]
   \[
   m(l - n) = -a
   \]
   \[
   m \cdot 2 = -a
   \]
   \[
   m = -\frac{a}{2}
   \]

8. Since \(m\) must be an integer, \(a\) must be even. Let \(a = 2k\) for some integer \(k\).

9. Substituting \(m = -k\) into the equations for the roots, we get:
   \[
   l = -k + 2 \quad \text{and} \quad n = -k - 2
   \]

10. Using the product of the roots \(lm = b + 1\), we have:
    \[
    (-k + 2)(-k) = b + 1
    \]
    \[
    k^2 - 2k = b + 1
    \]
    \[
    b = k^2 - 2k - 1
    \]

11. Since \(b\) must be a positive integer less than 1000, we have:
    \[
    1 \leq k^2 - 2k - 1 < 1000
    \]
    \[
    2 \leq k^2 - 2k < 1001
    \]
    \[
    2 \leq k(k - 2) < 1001
    \]

12. Solving the inequality \(2 \leq k(k - 2) < 1001\):
    \[
    k^2 - 2k - 1001 < 0
    \]
    \[
    k^2 - 2k - 1001 = 0
    \]
    Solving this quadratic equation using the quadratic formula \(k = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\):
    \[
    k = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4 + 4004}}{2} = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4008}}{2} = \frac{2 \pm 2\sqrt{1002}}{2} = 1 \pm \sqrt{1002}
    \]
    Since \(k\) must be an integer, we take the positive root:
    \[
    1 \leq k \leq \lfloor \sqrt{1002} \rfloor = 31
    \]

13. Therefore, \(k\) ranges from 2 to 31, inclusive. This gives us 30 possible values for \(k\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{30}\)
informal_statement: Let $P(x) = x^2 + ax + b$ be a quadratic polynomial. For how many pairs $(a, b)$ of positive integers where $a, b < 1000$ do the quadratics $P(x+1)$ and $P(x) + 1$ have at least one root in common?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $P(x) = x^2 + ax + b$ be a quadratic polynomial. For how many pairs $(a, b)$ of positive integers where $a, b < 1000$ do the quadratics $P(x+1)$ and $P(x) + 1$ have at least one root in common? -/
theorem algebra_38822 :
    Set.ncard {p : â„• Ã— â„• | p.1 > 0 âˆ§ p.2 > 0 âˆ§ p.1 < 1000 âˆ§ p.2 < 1000 âˆ§
      âˆƒ x, x^2 + p.1 * x + p.2 = (x + 1)^2 + p.1 * (x + 1) + p.2 + 1} = 30 := by

soln_description:
Prove
$$\frac{a_{1}}{1+a_{2}+a_{3}+\cdots+a_{n}}+1=\frac{1+\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3} \cdots+a_{n}\right)}{2-a_{1}}=\frac{2}{2-a_{1}}$$

Similarly,
$$\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a_{2}}{1+a_{1}+a_{3}+\cdots+a_{n}}+\Gamma=\frac{2}{2-a_{2}}, \cdots, \\
\frac{a_{n}}{1+a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n-1}}+1=\frac{2}{2-a_{n}}
\end{array}$$

Let
$$\begin{array}{l}
y=\frac{a_{1}}{1+a_{2}+a_{3}+\cdots+a_{i}}+\frac{a_{2}}{1+a_{1}+a_{3}+\cdots+a_{n}}+\cdots+ \\
\frac{a_{n}}{1+a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}
\end{array}$$

Therefore,
$$y+n=\frac{a_{1}}{2-a_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}}{2-a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{2-a_{n}}+n=\frac{1}{2-a_{1}}+\frac{1}{2-a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2-a_{n}}$$

To apply the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, note that
$$\left(2-a_{1}\right)+\left(2-a_{2}\right)+\cdots+\left(2-a_{n}\right)=2 n-\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)=2 n-1$$

Thus,
$$\begin{array}{l}
(2 n-1)\left(\frac{1}{2-a_{1}}+\frac{1}{2-a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2-a_{n}}\right)= \\
{\left[\left(2-a_{1}\right)+\left(2-a_{2}\right)+\cdots+\left(2-a_{n}\right)\right]\left(\frac{1}{2-a_{1}}+\frac{1}{2-a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{2-a_{n}}\right) \geqslant}
\end{array}$$
$n^{2}$ (Corollary 1)
Hence,
$$y+n \geqslant \frac{2 n^{2}}{2 n-1}, y \geqslant \frac{2 n^{2}}{2 n-1}-n=\frac{n}{2 n-1}$$

Equality holds if and only if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n}=\frac{1}{n}$, thus $y$ has a minimum value of $\frac{n}{2 n-1}$.

\[ 2\left [ P(x) - P\left ( \frac{1}{x} \right ) \right ]^2 + 3P(x^2)P\left ( \frac{1}{x^2} \right ) = 0 \]

theorem algebra_4614 {P : Polynomial â„} (hP : âˆ€ x : â„, x â‰  0 â†’ 2 * (P.eval x - P.eval (1 / x))^2 + 3 * P.eval (x^2) * P.eval (1 / x^2) = 0) :
    âˆ€ n : â„•, P.coeff n = 0 := by

informal_statement: Find the value of $x$ such that $ \sqrt { x } = x - 42 $.
informal_proof:
We are given a real number `x` such that `x â‰¥ 0` and `âˆšx = x - 42`. Our goal is to prove that `x = 49`.

First, we establish a necessary condition on `x`. By definition, the square root of a non-negative real number is non-negative, so `âˆšx â‰¥ 0`. From the given equation, this implies that `x - 42` must also be non-negative.
```
x - 42 = âˆšx â‰¥ 0
```
This gives us the inequality `x â‰¥ 42`.

Next, to eliminate the square root, we square both sides of the original equation `âˆšx = x - 42`:
```
(âˆšx)Â² = (x - 42)Â²
```
Since we are given that `x â‰¥ 0`, the left side simplifies to `x`:
```
x = (x - 42)Â²
```
We expand the right side of the equation:
```
(x - 42)Â² = xÂ² - 2(x)(42) + 42Â² = xÂ² - 84x + 1764
```
Substituting this back, we get a quadratic equation:
```
x = xÂ² - 84x + 1764
```
By subtracting `x` from both sides, we rearrange it into standard form:
```
xÂ² - 85x + 1764 = 0
```
This quadratic equation can be factored as:
```
(x - 36)(x - 49) = 0
```
By the zero-product property, this equation holds if and only if `x - 36 = 0` or `x - 49 = 0`. This gives us two potential solutions: `x = 36` and `x = 49`.

We now check these potential solutions against the necessary condition `x â‰¥ 42` that we derived earlier.

1.  **Case 1: `x = 36`**. This value contradicts the condition `x â‰¥ 42`. Therefore, `x = 36` is an extraneous solution introduced by squaring and is not a valid solution to the original equation.

2.  **Case 2: `x = 49`**. This value satisfies the condition `49 â‰¥ 42`. Therefore, `x = 49` is a valid solution.

Since `x = 49` is the only valid solution, we conclude that `x = 49`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the value of $x$ such that $ \sqrt { x } = x - 42 $. -/
theorem algebra_9532 {x : â„} (hx : 0 â‰¤ x) (h : Real.sqrt x = x - 42) : x = 49 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_9532 {x : â„} (hx : 0 â‰¤ x) (h : Real.sqrt x = x - 42) : x = 49 := by
  have h1 : Real.sqrt x â‰¥ 0 := Real.sqrt_nonneg x
  have h2 : x - 42 â‰¥ 0 := by linarith [h, h1]
  have h3 : Real.sqrt x ^ 2 = (x - 42) ^ 2 := by 
    rw [h]
  have h4 : (Real.sqrt x) ^ 2 = x := by
    rw [Real.sq_sqrt hx]
  rw [h4] at h3
  have h5 : (x - 42) ^ 2 = x^2 - 84 * x + 1764 := by
    ring
  rw [h5] at h3
  have h6 : x^2 - 85 * x + 1764 = 0 := by
    nlinarith
  have h7 : (x - 36) * (x - 49) = 0 := by
    nlinarith [h6]
  cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 h7) with h8 h9
  Â· -- case $x - 36 = 0$, so $x = 36$, which contradicts $x \geq 42$
    linarith
  Â· -- case $x - 49 = 0$, so $x = 49$
    linarith

soln_description:
# Solution:

Let $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$.

The equations from the problem can be transformed (by moving to the left side of the equation, grouping) to the following form: $a x^{2}+(b-1) x+(c+1)=0$ and $a x^{2}+(b+2) x+(c-2)=0$.

From the condition, it follows that their discriminants are equal to $0: D_{1}=(b-1)^{2}-4 a(c+1)=0$, similarly $D_{2}=(b+2)^{2}-4 a(c-2)=0$.

If we multiply $D_{1}$ by 2, add $D_{2}$, and divide the result by 3, we get $b^{2}-4 a c+2=0$, from which $b^{2}-4 a c=-2$,

which means the equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ has a negative discriminant, and therefore has no real roots.

## Criteria:

Correctly written conditions for each discriminant being equal to zero - 2 points.

soln_description:
Prove that the original inequality is equivalent to
$$a b c+3 \sum a^{2} b \geqslant 2 \sum a^{2} c$$
(1) If $a \geqslant b \geqslant c$, then
$$(a-b)(b-c)(c-a) \leqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow \sum a^{2} b \geqslant \sum a^{2} c$$

In this case, the original inequality clearly holds.
(2) If $a \geqslant c \geqslant b$, rewrite the original inequality as
$$(3 a-2 b) c^{2}+\left(3 b^{2}+a b-2 a^{2}\right) c+3 a^{2} b-2 a b^{2} \geqslant 0$$

The above is a quadratic function in terms of $c$, and
$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta= & \left(3 b^{2}+a b-2 a^{2}\right)^{2}-4(3 a-2 b)\left(3 a^{2} b-2 a b^{2}\right)= \\
& 9 b^{4}+37 a^{2} b^{2}+4 a^{4}-10 a b\left(b^{2}+4 a^{2}\right)= \\
& \left(b^{2}+4 a^{2}\right)(9 b-a)(b-a) \leqslant 0
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the original inequality holds.

soln_description:
## Second solution.

Let $x=\overline{a b c}$ be the desired number.

According to the condition of the problem, $\overline{a b c}=3(a+b+c)^{2}$.

Obviously, the desired number is divisible by 3, and then the sum of its digits is also divisible by 3, i.e., $a+b+c=3 k, k \in \mathbb{N}$.

Then $\overline{a b c}=3(a+b+c)^{2}=27 k^{2}$.

This will be a three-digit number if $k^{2} \in\{4,9,16,25,36\}$. 1 point

It follows that $\overline{a b c} \in\{108,243,432,675,972\}$.

By direct verification, we conclude that the numbers satisfying the conditions of the problem are

$243=3(2+4+3)^{2}$ and $972=3(9+7+2)^{2}$.
informal_statement:
## Task B-1.5.

Determine all three-digit numbers that are three times greater than the square of the sum of their digits.
informal_proof:
We are asked to prove that for any natural number `n` between 100 and 999 (inclusive), the statement `n = 3 * (sum of digits of n)Â²` is true if and only if `n = 243` or `n = 972`.

The proof consists of two parts, corresponding to the two directions of the "if and only if" statement.

**Part 1: Forward Direction (â‡’)**

First, we prove that if `n` is a three-digit number satisfying `n = 3 * (sum of digits of n)Â²`, then `n` must be either 243 or 972.

The proof proceeds by an exhaustive computational check of every integer `n` from 100 to 999. For each `n` in this range, we evaluate the condition `n = 3 * (sum of digits of n)Â²`.

- For `n = 100`: The sum of digits is `1 + 0 + 0 = 1`. Then, `3 * 1Â² = 3`. Since `100 â‰  3`, the condition is false.
- ...
- For `n = 243`: The sum of digits is `2 + 4 + 3 = 9`. Then, `3 * 9Â² = 3 * 81 = 243`. Since `243 = 243`, the condition is true.
- ...
- For `n = 972`: The sum of digits is `9 + 7 + 2 = 18`. Then, `3 * 18Â² = 3 * 324 = 972`. Since `972 = 972`, the condition is true.
- ...
- For `n = 999`: The sum of digits is `9 + 9 + 9 = 27`. Then, `3 * 27Â² = 3 * 729 = 2187`. Since `999 â‰  2187`, the condition is false.

By carrying out this check for all 900 integers from 100 to 999, we find that the only numbers that satisfy the equation are 243 and 972. Therefore, this direction of the implication holds.

**Part 2: Backward Direction (â‡)**

Next, we prove that if `n = 243` or `n = 972`, then `n = 3 * (sum of digits of n)Â²`. We consider each case separately.

**Case 1: `n = 243`**
We substitute `n = 243` into the equation and verify its truth.
- The sum of the digits of 243 is `2 + 4 + 3 = 9`.
- The expression `3 * (sum of digits of n)Â²` becomes `3 * 9Â² = 3 * 81 = 243`.
- Since this value is equal to `n`, the equation holds for `n = 243`.

**Case 2: `n = 972`**
We substitute `n = 972` into the equation and verify its truth.
- The sum of the digits of 972 is `9 + 7 + 2 = 18`.
- The expression `3 * (sum of digits of n)Â²` becomes `3 * 18Â² = 3 * 324 = 972`.
- Since this value is equal to `n`, the equation holds for `n = 972`.

Since the equation holds in both cases, this direction of the implication is proven.

Having established both the forward (â‡’) and backward (â‡) directions, we conclude that the equivalence is true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task B-1.5.

Determine all three-digit numbers that are three times greater than the square of the sum of their digits. -/
theorem number_theory_234201 (n : â„•) (hâ‚€ : n âˆˆ Finset.Icc 100 999) :
    n = 3 * (Nat.digits 10 n).sum^2 â†” n = 243 âˆ¨ n = 972 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_234201 (n : â„•) (hâ‚€ : n âˆˆ Finset.Icc 100 999) :
    n = 3 * (Nat.digits 10 n).sum^2 â†” n = 243 âˆ¨ n = 972 := by
  rw [Finset.mem_Icc] at hâ‚€
  rcases hâ‚€ with âŸ¨h1, h2âŸ©
  constructor
  Â· -- Forward direction
    intro h
    interval_cases n <;> norm_num at h âŠ¢ <;> tauto
  Â· -- Backward direction
    rintro (h | h)
    Â· -- First case
      rw [h]
      norm_num
    Â· -- Second case
      rw [h]
      norm_num

soln_description:
(1) For any $0 < x_1 < x_2$, we have $\frac{x_1 + 1}{x_2 + 1} > \frac{x_1}{x_2}$, thus $\lg \frac{x_1 + 1}{x_2 + 1} > \lg \frac{x_1}{x_2}$. Therefore,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x_1) - f(x_2) > \lg \frac{x_1}{x_2} - \log \frac{x_1}{x_2} \\
= \lg \frac{x_1}{x_2} - \frac{\lg \frac{x_1}{x_2}}{\lg 9}.
\end{array}
$$

Since $0 < \frac{x_1}{x_2} < 1$, we have $\lg \frac{x_1}{x_2} < 0$. Therefore,
$$
\lg \frac{x_1}{x_2} - \frac{\lg \frac{x_1}{x_2}}{\lg 9} > \lg \frac{x_1}{x_2} - \lg \frac{x_1}{x_2} = 0.
$$

Hence, $f(x)$ is a decreasing function on $(0, +\infty)$.
Noting that $f(9) = 0$, we have:
When $x > 9$, $f(x) < f(9) = 0$.
When $x < 9$, $f(x) > f(9) = 0$.
Therefore, $f(x) = 0$ has and only has one root $x = 9$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(2) From } f(n^2 - 214n - 1998) \geq 0 \\
\Rightarrow f(n^2 - 214n - 1998) \geq f(9). \\
\text{Then }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
n^2 - 214n - 1998 \leq 9, \\
n^2 - 214n - 1998 > 0
\end{array}\right. \\
\Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}
n^2 - 214n - 2007 \leq 0, \\
n^2 - 214n - 1998 > 0
\end{array}\right. \\
\Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}
(n - 223)(n + 9) \leq 0, \\
(n - 107)^2 > 1998 + 107^2 = 13447 > 115^2
\end{array}\right. \\
\Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-9 \leq n \leq 223, \\
n > 222 \text{ or } n < -8
\end{array}\right. \\
\Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}
-9 \leq n \leq 223, \\
n \geq 223 \text{ or } n \leq -9.
\end{array}\right. \\
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $n = 223$ or $n = -9$.
Hence, $M = \{-9, 223\}$.
Therefore, the number of subsets of $M$ is 4.

soln_description:
[Proof] Take any two numbers $a$ and $b$ from 48 natural numbers, and according to the given, we can write
$$
a b=p_{1}^{a_{1}} p_{2}^{\alpha_{2} \cdots} p_{10}^{a_{10}},
$$

where $p_{1}, p_{2}, \cdots, p_{10}$ are 10 different known primes and $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \cdots, \alpha_{10}$ are all non-negative integers. Define the mapping
$$
(a, b) \longrightarrow\left\{\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \cdots, \alpha_{10}\right\}.
$$

Since there are $C_{48}^{2}=1128$ different pairs $(a, b)$, and the ten-tuple $\left\{\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \cdots, \alpha_{10}\right\}$ has $2^{10}=1024$ possibilities based on parity, by the pigeonhole principle, there exist two different pairs $(a, b)$ and $(c, d)$ whose corresponding ten-tuples have the same parity. Thus, $a b c d$ is a perfect square.

If $a, b, c, d$ are all distinct, then they are the desired numbers; if $b=d$, then $a c$ is a perfect square.

Excluding the two numbers $a$ and $c$, the number of different pairs formed by the remaining 46 numbers is $C_{46}^{2}=$ $1035>2^{10}$, so we can repeat the above process to find two different pairs $(x, y)$ and $(z, t)$ such that $x y z t$ is a perfect square. If $x, y, z, t$ are all distinct, then they are the desired numbers; if $y=t$, then $x z$ is a perfect square, and thus $a, c, x, z$ are the desired numbers.
informal_statement: $2 \cdot 19$ Given that the product of 48 natural numbers has exactly 10 different prime factors. Prove that it is possible to select 4 numbers from the 48 numbers such that the product of these 4 numbers is a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $2 \cdot 19$ Given that the product of 48 natural numbers has exactly 10 different prime factors. Prove that it is possible to select 4 numbers from the 48 numbers such that the product of these 4 numbers is a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_113314 (a : Fin 48 â†’ â„•) (ha : âˆ€ i, a i > 0)
    (h : (Nat.primeFactors (âˆ i, a i)).card = 10) :
    âˆƒ b : Finset (Fin 48), b.card = 4 âˆ§ âˆƒ m, m^2 = âˆ i âˆˆ b, a i := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( n - 3 = k^3 \) for some integer \( k \). Then \( n = k^3 + 3 \).
2. We need \( n^2 + 4 \) to be a perfect cube. Substituting \( n = k^3 + 3 \), we get:
   \[
   n^2 + 4 = (k^3 + 3)^2 + 4
   \]
3. Expanding the square, we have:
   \[
   (k^3 + 3)^2 + 4 = k^6 + 6k^3 + 9 + 4 = k^6 + 6k^3 + 13
   \]
4. We need \( k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 \) to be a perfect cube. Let \( k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 = m^3 \) for some integer \( m \).
5. To find possible values of \( k \), we analyze the equation modulo 9. The cubes modulo 9 are \( 0, 1, -1 \). We need to check if \( k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 \equiv 0, 1, -1 \pmod{9} \).

   - For \( k \equiv 0 \pmod{3} \):
     \[
     k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 \equiv 0 + 0 + 13 \equiv 4 \pmod{9} \quad (\text{not a cube})
     \]
   - For \( k \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \):
     \[
     k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 \equiv 1 + 6 + 13 \equiv 20 \equiv 2 \pmod{9} \quad (\text{not a cube})
     \]
   - For \( k \equiv 2 \pmod{3} \):
     \[
     k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 \equiv 1 + 6 + 13 \equiv 20 \equiv 2 \pmod{9} \quad (\text{not a cube})
     \]

6. We need to check small values of \( k \) to find if any satisfy the condition \( k^6 + 6k^3 + 13 = m^3 \):
   - For \( k = -1 \):
     \[
     (-1)^6 + 6(-1)^3 + 13 = 1 - 6 + 13 = 8 = 2^3 \quad (\text{a cube})
     \]
     Thus, \( n = (-1)^3 + 3 = -1 + 3 = 2 \).
   - For \( k = 2 \):
     \[
     2^6 + 6 \cdot 2^3 + 13 = 64 + 48 + 13 = 125 = 5^3 \quad (\text{a cube})
     \]
     Thus, \( n = 2^3 + 3 = 8 + 3 = 11 \).

7. The possible values of \( n \) are \( 2 \) and \( 11 \). Summing these values, we get:
   \[
   2 + 11 = 13
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{13}\)

import Mathlib

    âˆ‘á¶  n âˆˆ {n : â„¤ | âˆƒ a b, n - 3 = a^3 âˆ§ n^2 + 4 = b^3}, n = 13 := by

informal_statement: Find the distance between the planes $x + 2y - 2z + 1 = 0$ and $2x + 4y - 4z + 5 = 0.$
informal_proof:
We aim to prove the equality:
$$ \frac{\left| \frac{1}{2} - \frac{5}{4} \right|}{\sqrt{\frac{1^2 + 2^2 + (-2)^2}{4}}} = \frac{1}{2} $$
The proof proceeds by simplifying the numerator and the denominator of the expression on the left-hand side separately.

**Step 1: Simplify the numerator**

First, we establish that the numerator, $\left| \frac{1}{2} - \frac{5}{4} \right|$, is equal to $\frac{3}{4}$.
The subtraction within the absolute value gives:
$$ \frac{1}{2} - \frac{5}{4} = \frac{2}{4} - \frac{5}{4} = -\frac{3}{4} $$
Since $-\frac{3}{4}$ is a negative number, its absolute value is $- (-\frac{3}{4}) = \frac{3}{4}$.
Thus, we have shown that $\left| \frac{1}{2} - \frac{5}{4} \right| = \frac{3}{4}$.

**Step 2: Simplify the denominator**

Next, we establish that the denominator, $\sqrt{\frac{1^2 + 2^2 + (-2)^2}{4}}$, is equal to $\frac{3}{2}$.
We begin by calculating the expression inside the square root:
$$ \frac{1^2 + 2^2 + (-2)^2}{4} = \frac{1 + 4 + 4}{4} = \frac{9}{4} $$
So the denominator is $\sqrt{\frac{9}{4}}$. To prove that $\sqrt{\frac{9}{4}} = \frac{3}{2}$, we use the property that for non-negative real numbers $x$ and $y$, $\sqrt{x} = y$ if and only if $x = y^2$. We must verify two conditions:
1. The term we are taking the square root of is equal to the square of our result: $(\frac{3}{2})^2 = \frac{9}{4}$. This is true.
2. The result is non-negative: $\frac{3}{2} \ge 0$. This is also true.
Therefore, we have shown that $\sqrt{\frac{1^2 + 2^2 + (-2)^2}{4}} = \frac{3}{2}$.

**Step 3: Final Calculation**

Having simplified the numerator and the denominator, we substitute these values back into the original equation. The left-hand side becomes:
$$ \frac{3/4}{3/2} $$
Performing the division of fractions:
$$ \frac{3/4}{3/2} = \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{2}{3} = \frac{6}{12} = \frac{1}{2} $$
This result matches the right-hand side of the equation. Thus, the equality is proven.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the distance between the planes $x + 2y - 2z + 1 = 0$ and $2x + 4y - 4z + 5 = 0.$ -/
theorem calculus_12733 :
    abs (1 / 2 - (5 / 4)) / Real.sqrt ((1 ^ 2 + 2 ^ 2 + (-2) ^ 2) / 4) = 1 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem calculus_12733 :
    abs (1 / 2 - (5 / 4)) / Real.sqrt ((1 ^ 2 + 2 ^ 2 + (-2) ^ 2) / 4) = 1 / 2 := by
  have h1 : abs (1 / 2 - (5 / 4) : â„) = (3 / 4 : â„) := by 
    norm_num [abs_of_neg]
  have h2 : Real.sqrt ((1 ^ 2 + 2 ^ 2 + (-2) ^ 2 : â„) / 4) = (3 / 2 : â„) := by
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
  rw [h1, h2]
  all_goals norm_num
  <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num

soln_description:
Answer: There are no solutions.

Solution. Let $y_{k}$ be the number of passengers in the carriage with number $k, k=1,2,3, \ldots, 12$. According to the problem, $\sum_{k=1}^{12} y_{k}=384$. Additionally, it is stated that $y_{2} \geq y_{1}+3, y_{3} \geq y_{1}+6, \ldots, y_{11} \geq y_{1}+30, y_{12} \geq y_{1}+33$. Adding these inequalities,

$$
y_{2}+y_{3}+\ldots+y_{11}+y_{12} \geq y_{1}+3+y_{1}+6+\ldots+y_{1}+30+y_{1}+33
$$

or

$$
384-y_{1} \geq 11 y_{1}+198
$$

From this, we get $y_{1} \leq \frac{186}{12}=\frac{31}{2}=15.5$. Since $y_{1}$ is a natural number, then $y_{1} \leq 15$. From the conditions $y_{12} \geq y_{1}+33$ and $y_{12} \leq 3 y_{1}$, it follows that $3 y_{1} \geq y_{1}+33$ or $y_{1} \geq \frac{33}{2}=16.5$. Since $y_{1}$ is a natural number, then $y_{1} \geq 17$. The system $\left\{\begin{array}{l}y_{1} \leq 15, \\ y_{1} \geq 17,\end{array}\right.$ has no solutions.
informal_statement: 1. There are 12 carriages in the train, and they contain 384 passengers. In the second carriage, there are more than two passengers more than in the first, in the third carriage, there are more than two passengers more than in the second, and so on until the last carriage. The number of passengers in the last carriage does not exceed three times the number of passengers in the first carriage. How many passengers are in the first carriage?

    Â¬âˆƒ p : Fin 12 â†’ â„•, (âˆ€ i j, i < j â†’ p i + 2 â‰¤ p j) âˆ§ (âˆ‘ i, p i = 384) := by

$\textbf{(A)}\ \frac{n}{2} \qquad\textbf{(B)}\ \frac{n^2}{2}\qquad\textbf{(C)}\ n\qquad\textbf{(D)}\ \frac{n-1}{2}\qquad\textbf{(E)}\ \frac{n+1}{2}$

    (Finset.sum (Finset.range n) (fun i => (i + 1))) / n = (n + 1) / 2 := by

soln_description:
Prove on one hand: $y z+z x+x y-2 x y z=(y z+z x+x y)(x+y+z)-2 x y z$
$$=\sum x^{2}(y+z)+x y z \geqslant 0$$

On the other hand: 7-27 $(y z+z x+x y-2 x y z)=7(x+y+z)^{3}-27[(y z+z x+x y)(x+y+z)-2 x y z]$
$$\begin{array}{l}
=7 \sum x^{3}-6 \sum x^{2}(y+z)+15 x y z \\
\left.\geqslant 6 \sum x^{3}-6 \sum x^{2}(y+z)+18 x y z \text { (since } \sum x^{3} \geqslant 3 x y z\right) \\
\geqslant 0 \text { (by (1) ). }
\end{array}$$

Therefore, the original proposition holds.

soln_description:
Answer: $\square$
Since $a \circ b=(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b})^{2}$, we have $x^{2} \circ 9 x=(x+3 \sqrt{x})^{2}$. Moreover, since $x$ is positive, we have $x+3 \sqrt{x}=11$, and the only possible solution is that $\sqrt{x}=\frac{-3+\sqrt{53}}{2}$, so $x=\frac{31-3 \sqrt{53}}{2}$.
informal_statement: 7. [6] For any positive real numbers $a$ and $b$, define $a \circ b=a+b+2 \sqrt{a b}$. Find all positive real numbers $x$ such that $x^{2} \circ 9 x=121$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 7. [6] For any positive real numbers $a$ and $b$, define $a \circ b=a+b+2 \sqrt{a b}$. Find all positive real numbers $x$ such that $x^{2} \circ 9 x=121$. -/
theorem algebra_159886 (x : â„) (hx : x > 0) :
    (x^2 + 9 * x + 2 * sqrt (x^2 * 9 * x)) = 121 â†”
    x = (31 - 3 * sqrt 53) / 2 := by

informal_statement: Find the sum of all $p$ such that $p$ and $p^2 + 20$ are prime numbers.
informal_proof:
The goal is to compute the sum of all prime numbers `p` for which `p^2 + 20` is also prime. We will first identify the set of such primes and then compute the sum.

Let `S = {p : â„• | p is prime âˆ§ p^2 + 20 is prime}`. We will show that `S = {3}`. This is proven by showing that any element of `S` must be `3`, and conversely, that `3` is an element of `S`.

**Part 1: Show that if `p âˆˆ S`, then `p = 3`.**

Let `p` be a natural number such that `p` is prime and `p^2 + 20` is prime. We consider two cases based on the value of `p`.

*   **Case 1: `p â‰¤ 3`**
    Since `p` is prime, the only possibilities are `p = 2` or `p = 3`.
    *   If `p = 2`, then `p^2 + 20 = 2^2 + 20 = 24`. Since 24 is not prime, `p=2` is not in `S`.
    *   If `p = 3`, then `p^2 + 20 = 3^2 + 20 = 29`. Since 3 and 29 are both prime, `p=3` is in `S`.
    Therefore, if `p â‰¤ 3`, we must have `p = 3`.

*   **Case 2: `p > 3`**
    Since `p` is a prime number greater than 3, `p` cannot be a multiple of 3. By the division algorithm, the remainder of `p` when divided by 3 must be either 1 or 2.
    *   **Subcase 2a: `p â‰¡ 1 (mod 3)`**.
        If `p` leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 3, then `p^2` leaves a remainder of `1^2 = 1`. The number `20` leaves a remainder of `2` when divided by 3 (since `20 = 3 Ã— 6 + 2`).
        Therefore, `p^2 + 20 â‰¡ 1 + 2 â‰¡ 3 â‰¡ 0 (mod 3)`.
        This means `p^2 + 20` is divisible by 3. Since `p > 3`, we have `p^2 > 9`, so `p^2 + 20 > 29`. As `p^2 + 20` is a multiple of 3 and is strictly greater than 3, it cannot be a prime number. This contradicts our assumption that `p^2 + 20` is prime.

    *   **Subcase 2b: `p â‰¡ 2 (mod 3)`**.
        If `p` leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3, then `p^2` leaves a remainder of `2^2 = 4`, which is `1 (mod 3)`.
        Again, `p^2 + 20 â‰¡ 1 + 2 â‰¡ 0 (mod 3)`.
        As in the previous subcase, this implies `p^2 + 20` is a multiple of 3 greater than 3, which contradicts the assumption that `p^2 + 20` is prime.

Since both subcases for `p > 3` lead to a contradiction, the assumption that `p > 3` must be false. Combining this with the analysis of the `p â‰¤ 3` case, we conclude that the only possibility is `p = 3`.

**Part 2: Show that `3 âˆˆ S`.**

This is a straightforward verification.
1.  Is `p = 3` prime? Yes.
2.  Is `p^2 + 20` prime? For `p=3`, this is `3^2 + 20 = 9 + 20 = 29`. Yes, 29 is prime.
Since both conditions are met, `3` is in `S`.

From both parts, we have established that `S = {3}`.

**Part 3: Compute the sum.**

The problem asks for the sum `âˆ‘á¶  p âˆˆ S, p`. Substituting `S = {3}`, the expression becomes:
`âˆ‘á¶  p âˆˆ {3}, p`
The finite sum of a function over a singleton set is the value of the function at that single element. Here, the function is the identity `f(p) = p`. Therefore, the sum is simply `3`.

Thus, we have proven that `âˆ‘á¶  p âˆˆ {p : â„• | Nat.Prime p âˆ§ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20)}, p = 3`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the sum of all $p$ such that $p$ and $p^2 + 20$ are prime numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_13657 :
    âˆ‘á¶  p âˆˆ {p : â„• | Nat.Prime p âˆ§ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20)}, p = 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_13657 :
    âˆ‘á¶  p âˆˆ {p : â„• | Nat.Prime p âˆ§ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20)}, p = 3 := by
  have h1 : {p : â„• | Nat.Prime p âˆ§ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20)} = {3} := by
    ext p
    simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_singleton_iff]
    constructor
    Â· -- Assume Nat.Prime p âˆ§ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20), prove p = 3
      intro h
      rcases h with âŸ¨h1, h2âŸ©
      by_cases h3 : p â‰¤ 3
      Â· -- p â‰¤ 3
        interval_cases p <;> norm_num at h1 h2 âŠ¢ <;> tauto
      Â· -- Assume p > 3
        have h4 : p > 3 := by linarith
        have h5 : p % 3 = 0 âˆ¨ p % 3 = 1 âˆ¨ p % 3 = 2 := by
          omega
        rcases h5 with (h5 | h5 | h5)
        Â· -- Case p â‰¡ 0 mod 3
          have h6 : p % 3 = 0 := h5
          have h7 : Â¬ Nat.Prime p := by 
            apply Nat.not_prime_of_dvd_of_lt (show 3 âˆ£ p by omega)
            all_goals linarith
          contradiction
        Â· -- Case p â‰¡ 1 mod 3
          have h8 : p % 3 = 1 := h5
          have h9 : (p ^ 2 + 20) % 3 = 0 := by
            have h10 : p ^ 2 % 3 = 1 := by
              have h11 : p % 3 = 1 := h8
              norm_num [Nat.pow_mod, h11]
            omega
          have h10 : Â¬ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20) := by 
            apply Nat.not_prime_of_dvd_of_lt (show 3 âˆ£ p ^ 2 + 20 by omega)
            all_goals nlinarith
          contradiction
        Â· -- Case p â‰¡ 2 mod 3
          have h12 : p % 3 = 2 := h5
          have h9 : (p ^ 2 + 20) % 3 = 0 := by
            have h10 : p ^ 2 % 3 = 1 := by
              have h11 : p % 3 = 2 := h12
              norm_num [Nat.pow_mod, h11]
            omega
          have h10 : Â¬ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20) := by 
            apply Nat.not_prime_of_dvd_of_lt (show 3 âˆ£ p ^ 2 + 20 by omega)
            all_goals nlinarith
          contradiction
    Â· -- Assume p = 3, prove Nat.Prime p âˆ§ Nat.Prime (p ^ 2 + 20)
      intro h
      rw [h]
      constructor
      Â· norm_num
      Â· norm_num
  rw [h1]
  rw [finsum_mem_singleton]
  all_goals norm_num

soln_description:
Solution to Exercise 7 For $\mathrm{n}=1$, if we start from a configuration with one column of two rows, with different integers on these two rows, the difference between the two integers remains invariant when one of the two operations is performed. Consequently, it cannot be canceled. In particular, Domitille cannot arrive at a rectangle containing only 0s in a finite number of steps.

We now assume that $n>2$. Consider the rectangle with one column of two rows with values 1 and 0. By looking at what happens modulo $n-1$, we see that multiplication by $n$ has no effect, and the second operation preserves the difference between the two values. Thus, the difference between the two values modulo $n-1$ is an invariant, initially non-zero. Consequently, it is impossible to make the two numbers equal $\bmod n-1$, and in particular to make them both zero.

Now let's show that Domitille can always reach 0 in the case $n=2$.

First, reduce the problem. If Domitille can handle the case where there is only one column, it is sufficient for her to deal with the columns one by one. Once a column is brought to 0, the only operation that its cells will undergo when processing the other columns will be the multiplication of a row by $\mathrm{n}$. But since the elements of the column are zero, this actually has no effect.

We can therefore assume that the rectangle is in fact composed of only one column. Then, if we can make two cells of the column equal, we can merge them, that is, each time we multiply the row of the first by $\mathrm{n}$, we do the same for the second. In this case, the two cells will always contain the same value. We can therefore restrict ourselves to the case where the column contains 2 cells with the integers $a$ and $b$. By multiplying each of the rows by 2, we can actually assume that $a$ and $b$ are even. We then subtract 2 from the smallest until it is 2. This is possible because neither $a$ nor $b$ is zero. Then we apply the "double then subtract" operation: we double the one that is 2, then subtract 2 from the column, until both numbers are 2. We have thus reduced to a configuration where all the numbers in the column are 2. We then subtract 2 from the column, and we have thus nullified the column, which concludes. Note also that the integers in all the other columns remain non-zero during all these manipulations.

Comments from the graders: Very few students tackled this problem, but those who did had excellent writing. Too bad some forgot the case $n=1$. One student attempted a proof by the principle of the minimum, which unfortunately did not lead to a conclusion.
informal_statement:
Exercise 7. Let $n$ be a strictly positive integer. Domitille has a rectangular grid divided into unit squares. Inside each unit square is written a strictly positive integer. She can perform the following operations as many times as she wishes:

- Choose a row and multiply each number in the row by $n$.
- Choose a column and subtract $n$ from each integer in the column.

Determine all values of $n$ for which the following property is satisfied:

Regardless of the dimensions of the rectangle and the integers written in the cells, Domitille can end up with a rectangle containing only 0s after a finite number of operations.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Exercise 7. Let $n$ be a strictly positive integer. Domitille has a rectangular grid divided into unit squares. Inside each unit square is written a strictly positive integer. She can perform the following operations as many times as she wishes:

- Choose a row and multiply each number in the row by $n$.
- Choose a column and subtract $n$ from each integer in the column.

Determine all values of $n$ for which the following property is satisfied:

Regardless of the dimensions of the rectangle and the integers written in the cells, Domitille can end up with a rectangle containing only 0s after a finite number of operations. -/
theorem number_theory_293808 (n : â„•) (hn : n > 0) :
    (âˆ€ k l, âˆƒ m p, k > 0 âˆ§ l > 0 âˆ§ m > 0 âˆ§ p > 0 âˆ§
      (k * n = m âˆ¨ l * n = m) âˆ§ (l * n - k = p)) â†” n = 2 := by

soln_description: Let's analyze: Suppose the greatest common divisor greater than 1 of $4 n+5$ and $7 n+6$ is $A$, then $A|(4 n+5), A|(7 n+6)$. Multiplying $(4 n+5)$ by 7 and $(7 n+6)$ by 4, and then subtracting to eliminate $n$, the difference is divisible by 11, $(4 n+5) \times 7 - (7 n+6) \times 4 = 11$, and 11 is a prime number, so $A$ can only be 11. $(4 n+5)$ and $(7 n+6)$ are both multiples of 11. To find all $n$, $2 \times (4 n+5) - (7 n+6) = n + 4$, and $11 \mid (n + 4)$, so $n = 7, 18, 29, 40$. Therefore, the answer is $7 + 18 + 29 + 40 = 94$.
informal_statement: 7. Let $n$ be a natural number less than 50, then the sum of all possible values of $n$ for which $4 n+5$ and $7 n+6$ have a common divisor greater than 1 is $\qquad$ .
informal_proof:
Let $S$ be the set of natural numbers $n$ such that $n < 50$ and the greatest common divisor of $4n+5$ and $7n+6$ is greater than 1. The problem is to compute the sum of all elements in $S$, which we denote as $\sum_{n \in S} n$.

The proof proceeds in two main steps. First, we will explicitly determine the elements of the set $S$. Second, we will sum these elements.

**Step 1: Determining the set S**

We will prove that $S = \{7, 18, 29, 40\}$. This is proven by showing containment in both directions.

**(a) Show that $\{7, 18, 29, 40\} \subseteq S$.**
We check each element individually to see if it satisfies the conditions for membership in $S$.

*   For $n=7$: We have $7 < 50$. We compute $\text{gcd}(4 \cdot 7 + 5, 7 \cdot 7 + 6) = \text{gcd}(33, 55) = 11$. Since $11 > 1$, $n=7$ is in $S$.
*   For $n=18$: We have $18 < 50$. We compute $\text{gcd}(4 \cdot 18 + 5, 7 \cdot 18 + 6) = \text{gcd}(77, 132) = 11$. Since $11 > 1$, $n=18$ is in $S$.
*   For $n=29$: We have $29 < 50$. We compute $\text{gcd}(4 \cdot 29 + 5, 7 \cdot 29 + 6) = \text{gcd}(121, 209) = 11$. Since $11 > 1$, $n=29$ is in $S$.
*   For $n=40$: We have $40 < 50$. We compute $\text{gcd}(4 \cdot 40 + 5, 7 \cdot 40 + 6) = \text{gcd}(165, 286) = 11$. Since $11 > 1$, $n=40$ is in $S$.

Since all four elements satisfy the conditions, we have shown that $\{7, 18, 29, 40\} \subseteq S$.

**(b) Show that $S \subseteq \{7, 18, 29, 40\}$.**
Let $n$ be an arbitrary element of $S$. By definition, $n$ is a natural number such that $n < 50$ and $\text{gcd}(4n+5, 7n+6) > 1$. The proof establishes this inclusion by performing an exhaustive case-by-case analysis for every possible value of $n$ in the range $0 \le n < 50$. For each $n$, the value of $\text{gcd}(4n+5, 7n+6)$ is computed. This computational check confirms that the condition $\text{gcd}(4n+5, 7n+6) > 1$ is satisfied only when $n$ is one of the values $7, 18, 29,$ or $40$. Therefore, if $n \in S$, it must be that $n \in \{7, 18, 29, 40\}$.

Combining both inclusions, we have established the set equality $S = \{7, 18, 29, 40\}$.

**Step 2: Computing the sum**

With the set $S$ explicitly identified, we can now compute the sum of its elements:
\[
\sum_{n \in S} n = \sum_{n \in \{7, 18, 29, 40\}} n
\]
This sum is calculated as:
\[
7 + 18 + 29 + 40 = 94
\]
Thus, the sum of all possible values of $n$ satisfying the given conditions is 94.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Let $n$ be a natural number less than 50, then the sum of all possible values of $n$ for which $4 n+5$ and $7 n+6$ have a common divisor greater than 1 is $\qquad$ .

 -/
theorem number_theory_102797 :
  âˆ‘á¶  n âˆˆ {n : â„• | n < 50 âˆ§ Nat.gcd (4 * n + 5) (7 * n + 6) > 1}, n = 94 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_102797 :
  âˆ‘á¶  n âˆˆ {n : â„• | n < 50 âˆ§ Nat.gcd (4 * n + 5) (7 * n + 6) > 1}, n = 94 := by
  have h1 : {n : â„• | n < 50 âˆ§ Nat.gcd (4 * n + 5) (7 * n + 6) > 1} = {7, 18, 29, 40} := by
    ext n
    simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_insert_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff, Set.union_insert, Set.union_singleton]
    constructor
    Â· intro h
      rcases h with âŸ¨h1, h2âŸ©
      interval_cases n <;> try { tauto }
      <;> norm_num at h1 h2 <;> omega
    Â· rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl)
      Â· constructor <;> norm_num [Nat.gcd]
      Â· constructor <;> norm_num [Nat.gcd]
      Â· constructor <;> norm_num [Nat.gcd]
      Â· constructor <;> norm_num [Nat.gcd]
  rw [h1]
  rw [finsum_mem_eq_toFinset_sum]
  simp [Set.mem_insert_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff, Set.union_insert, Set.union_singleton]
  <;> rfl

soln_description:
4. $\left(-\frac{\pi}{4}+k \pi, k \pi\right)(k \in \mathbf{Z})$.

Since
$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos ^{4} x-2 \sin x \cos x-\sin ^{4} x-1 & =\left(\cos ^{2} x+\sin ^{2} x\right)\left(\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{2} x\right)-2 \sin x \cos x \\
& =\cos 2 x-\sin 2 x=\sqrt{2} \cos \left(2 x+\frac{\pi}{4}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

the original inequality becomes
$$
\cos \left(2 x+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

Within $[0,2 \pi]$, the solution to $\cos \alpha>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ is $-\frac{\pi}{4}<\alpha<\frac{\pi}{4}$. Therefore, the solution to equation (1) is
$$
2 k \pi-\frac{\pi}{4}<2 x+\frac{\pi}{4}<2 k \pi+\frac{\pi}{4} \quad(k \in \mathbf{Z}),
$$

which means the solution to the original inequality is
$$
-\frac{\pi}{4}+k \pi<x<k \pi \quad(k \in \mathbf{Z}) .
$$
